title: Default and Keyword Arguments
objectives: Understand how to create optional parameters with default values
Learn to call functions using keyword (named) arguments
Master the difference between positional and keyword arguments
Write more flexible and user-friendly functions

sections.title: The Concept
sections.content:
ğŸ¨ Making Functions More Flexible

Real-World Analogy First:

Imagine ordering a coffee at your local cafÃ©:

  • â˜• Required: "I'd like a coffee" (you must specify you want coffee)
  • â˜• Optional with defaults: Size defaults to medium, milk defaults to regular, sugar defaults to none
  • â˜• Customize as needed: "Make it large with oat milk and 2 sugars"
  • â˜• Or just accept defaults: "Just a regular coffee" (gets medium, regular milk, no sugar)

You can also specify in any order: "I want oat milk, large size" or "Large with oat milk" - both work!

This is exactly how default arguments and keyword arguments work:

  • ğŸ”µ Default arguments: Parameters with preset values (optional)
  • ğŸ”µ Keyword arguments: Calling functions using parameter names
  • ğŸ”µ Flexibility: Specify only what you need to change

Now The Technical Terms:

Default Argument: A parameter that has a default value. If the caller doesn't provide a value, the default is used.

Keyword Argument: When calling a function, you can specify arguments by parameter name (size="large") instead of just position.

Positional Argument: Arguments matched to parameters by their position (first argument goes to first parameter, etc.).

Why This Matters:

  • âœ… Flexibility: Functions can have optional settings
  • âœ… Readability: Keyword arguments make code self-documenting
  • âœ… Convenience: Users don't need to specify every parameter
  • âœ… Backwards compatibility: Add new optional parameters without breaking existing code

sections.title: Code Example
sections.content:
ğŸ’» Default and Keyword Arguments in Action

Let's create functions with default parameters and call them different ways:
sections.code:
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 1: Function with Default Arguments
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

def greet(name, greeting="Hello", punctuation="!"):
    """Greet someone with customizable greeting and punctuation.
    
    Args:
        name: Person's name (required)
        greeting: Greeting word (default: "Hello")
        punctuation: Ending punctuation (default: "!")
    """
    message = f"{greeting}, {name}{punctuation}"
    print(message)

print("Example 1: Default arguments allow optional parameters")
print()

# Using all defaults (only required argument)
greet("Alice")  # Uses "Hello" and "!"

# Override one default
greet("Bob", "Hi")  # Uses "Hi" and "!"

# Override both defaults
greet("Carol", "Hey", ".")

print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 2: Keyword Arguments (Named Arguments)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

def create_user(username, email, age=18, active=True, admin=False):
    """Create a user account with optional settings.
    
    Args:
        username: User's username (required)
        email: User's email (required)
        age: User's age (default: 18)
        active: Account active status (default: True)
        admin: Admin privileges (default: False)
    """
    print(f"Creating user: {username}")
    print(f"  Email: {email}")
    print(f"  Age: {age}")
    print(f"  Active: {active}")
    print(f"  Admin: {admin}")
    print()

print("Example 2: Keyword arguments for clarity and flexibility")
print()

# Positional arguments (order matters)
create_user("alice123", "alice@email.com")

# Mix positional and keyword arguments
create_user("bob456", "bob@email.com", age=25)

# All keyword arguments (order doesn't matter!)
create_user(
    email="carol@email.com",
    username="carol789",
    admin=True,
    age=30
)

# Keyword arguments let you skip middle parameters
create_user("dave", "dave@email.com", admin=True)

print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 3: Practical Use Case - Drawing Function
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

def draw_box(width, height=None, border="*", fill=" "):
    """Draw a box with customizable appearance.
    
    Args:
        width: Width of box (required)
        height: Height of box (defaults to same as width for square)
        border: Character for border (default: "*")
        fill: Character for interior (default: " ")
    """
    # If height not specified, make it a square
    if height is None:
        height = width
    
    # Top border
    print(border * width)
    
    # Middle rows
    for _ in range(height - 2):
        print(border + fill * (width - 2) + border)
    
    # Bottom border
    if height > 1:
        print(border * width)

print("Example 3: Practical application")
print()

print("Simple square (5x5) with defaults:")
draw_box(5)
print()

print("Rectangle (8x4):")
draw_box(8, 4)
print()

print("Custom border and fill:")
draw_box(width=10, height=5, border="#", fill=".")
print()

print("Different border character:")
draw_box(7, border="+")

sections.title: Syntax Breakdown
sections.content:
ğŸ” Understanding Default and Keyword Arguments

Part 1: Defining Default Arguments

def greet(name, greeting="Hello"):
    #          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
    #          required  optional with default
  • ğŸ“Œ Syntax: parameter=default_value
  • ğŸ“Œ Parameters WITH defaults can be omitted when calling
  • ğŸ“Œ If omitted, the default value is used
  • ğŸ“Œ If provided, your value overrides the default

âš ï¸ Important Rule: Required Before Optional

# âœ… CORRECT: Required parameters first
def create_account(username, password, age=18):
    pass

# âŒ WRONG: Can't have required after optional
def create_account(username, age=18, password):
    pass  # SyntaxError!

Required (no default) parameters must come BEFORE optional (with default) parameters.

Part 2: Positional Arguments

def greet(name, greeting="Hello", punctuation="!"):
    pass

# Arguments matched by POSITION
greet("Alice", "Hi", ".")  
#      ^^^^^   ^^^^  ^^^  
#      name  greet punct
  • ğŸ“Œ Order matters!
  • ğŸ“Œ First argument goes to first parameter
  • ğŸ“Œ Second to second, etc.

Part 3: Keyword Arguments

# Arguments matched by NAME
greet(name="Alice", greeting="Hi", punctuation=".")
#     ^^^^^^^^^^^  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
#     Explicit parameter names

# Order doesn't matter with keyword arguments!
greet(punctuation=".", name="Alice", greeting="Hi")
  • ğŸ“Œ Use parameter_name=value
  • ğŸ“Œ Order doesn't matter
  • ğŸ“Œ Very clear what each argument means
  • ğŸ“Œ Can skip optional parameters in the middle

Part 4: Mixing Positional and Keyword

# âœ… CORRECT: Positional first, then keyword
greet("Alice", punctuation=".")
#     ^^^^^^   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
#     positional  keyword

# âŒ WRONG: Can't use positional after keyword
greet(name="Alice", "Hi")  # SyntaxError!

Rule: Once you use a keyword argument, all following arguments must also be keyword arguments.

Part 5: Benefits of Keyword Arguments

# Without keyword arguments - unclear what values mean
create_user("alice", "alice@email.com", 25, True, False)
#           What do True and False mean? Have to check definition!

# With keyword arguments - self-documenting
create_user("alice", "alice@email.com", age=25, active=True, admin=False)
#           Now it's clear what each value represents!

Part 6: Special Case - None as Default

def draw_box(width, height=None):
    # If not provided, calculate from width
    if height is None:
        height = width  # Make it a square
    # ... rest of function
  • ğŸ“Œ None is commonly used as default when you want to detect "not provided"
  • ğŸ“Œ Allows you to calculate defaults based on other parameters
  • ğŸ“Œ Different from 0 or "" which are actual values

Visual Model:

FUNCTION DEFINITION:
def greet(name, greeting="Hello", punctuation="!"):
          ^^^^  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
          REQ   OPTIONAL          OPTIONAL

CALLING OPTIONS:

1. greet("Alice")
   â†’ name="Alice", greeting="Hello", punctuation="!"

2. greet("Alice", "Hi")
   â†’ name="Alice", greeting="Hi", punctuation="!"

3. greet("Alice", punctuation="?")
   â†’ name="Alice", greeting="Hello", punctuation="?"
   (skipped middle parameter using keyword!)

4. greet(punctuation="?", name="Alice")
   â†’ name="Alice", greeting="Hello", punctuation="?"
   (order doesn't matter with all keywords!)

sections.title: Exercise
sections.content:
âœï¸ Your Turn: Pizza Order Function

Challenge: Create a function that takes a pizza order with customizable options.

Requirements:

  1. Function name: order_pizza
  2. Parameters:
    • size (required): "small", "medium", or "large"
    • crust (optional, default="regular"): Type of crust
    • cheese (optional, default="mozzarella"): Type of cheese
    • toppings (optional, default=[]): List of toppings
    • delivery (optional, default=False): Delivery or pickup
  3. The function should:
    • Print a formatted order summary
    • Calculate and return the total price
    • Base prices: small=$8, medium=$12, large=$16
    • Add $2 per topping
    • Add $3 if delivery is True
  4. Include a docstring

Test Cases:

# Basic order
total = order_pizza("medium")

# Custom order with keyword arguments
total = order_pizza(
    size="large",
    crust="thin",
    toppings=["pepperoni", "mushrooms", "olives"],
    delivery=True
)

# Another custom order
total = order_pizza("small", cheese="vegan", toppings=["peppers"])

Hint: Remember that empty lists as default arguments need special handling! Use None as default and create empty list inside function if needed.

sections.title: Solution
sections.code:
def order_pizza(size, crust="regular", cheese="mozzarella", toppings=None, delivery=False):
    """Take a pizza order and calculate the total price.
    
    Args:
        size: Pizza size - "small", "medium", or "large" (required)
        crust: Type of crust (default: "regular")
        cheese: Type of cheese (default: "mozzarella")
        toppings: List of toppings (default: [])
        delivery: Delivery or pickup (default: False)
    
    Returns:
        Total price of the order
    """
    # Handle default for toppings (important!)
    if toppings is None:
        toppings = []
    
    # Base prices
    prices = {"small": 8, "medium": 12, "large": 16}
    base_price = prices.get(size, 12)  # Default to medium if invalid size
    
    # Calculate total
    total = base_price
    total += len(toppings) * 2  # $2 per topping
    if delivery:
        total += 3  # $3 delivery fee
    
    # Print order summary
    print("\n" + "â”€" * 40)
    print(f"ğŸ• PIZZA ORDER")
    print("â”€" * 40)
    print(f"Size:     {size.capitalize()}")
    print(f"Crust:    {crust.capitalize()}")
    print(f"Cheese:   {cheese.capitalize()}")
    
    if toppings:
        print(f"Toppings: {', '.join(toppings).title()}")
    else:
        print(f"Toppings: None (cheese pizza)")
    
    print(f"Delivery: {'Yes' if delivery else 'No (Pickup)'}")
    print("â”€" * 40)
    print(f"Base price: ${base_price:.2f}")
    
    if toppings:
        print(f"Toppings:   ${len(toppings) * 2:.2f} ({len(toppings)} Ã— $2)")
    
    if delivery:
        print(f"Delivery:   $3.00")
    
    print(f"TOTAL:      ${total:.2f}")
    print("â”€" * 40)
    
    return total

ğŸ“š How It Works:

  1. Function Signature (Line 1):
    • size is REQUIRED (no default value)
    • crust="regular" is OPTIONAL (has default)
    • cheese="mozzarella" is OPTIONAL
    • toppings=None is OPTIONAL (None, not []!)
    • delivery=False is OPTIONAL
  2. Why toppings=None Instead of toppings=[]:
    # âŒ DANGEROUS - mutable default argument
def order_pizza(..., toppings=[]):
    # Same list object reused for all calls!
    # Toppings from previous orders persist!

# âœ… SAFE - use None and create new list each time
def order_pizza(..., toppings=None):
    if toppings is None:
        toppings = []  # Fresh list each time

    This is a Python gotcha! Mutable default arguments (lists, dicts) are created once and shared across all function calls.

  3. Flexible Calling Patterns:
    • order_pizza("medium") - Just required, all defaults
    • order_pizza("large", "thin") - Positional arguments
    • order_pizza("small", cheese="vegan") - Mix positional and keyword
    • order_pizza(size="large", delivery=True, toppings=[...]) - All keyword, any order
  4. Price Calculation (Lines 19-24):
    • Base price from size
    • Add $2 per topping (len(toppings) * 2)
    • Add $3 if delivery is True
  5. Formatted Output (Lines 27-50):
    • Shows complete order summary
    • Breaks down pricing
    • Makes it easy to verify order is correct

âš ï¸ Common Mistakes:

  1. Mutable Default Arguments:
    # âŒ WRONG - dangerous bug!
def order_pizza(size, toppings=[]):
    toppings.append("cheese")  # Modifies shared list!
    return toppings

order_pizza("medium")  # ["cheese"]
order_pizza("large")   # ["cheese", "cheese"] - WAT?!

# âœ… CORRECT
def order_pizza(size, toppings=None):
    if toppings is None:
        toppings = []
    toppings.append("cheese")  # Modifies fresh list
    return toppings
  2. Required After Optional:
    # âŒ WRONG - SyntaxError
def order_pizza(size="medium", crust):
    pass

# âœ… CORRECT - required first
def order_pizza(crust, size="medium"):
    pass
  3. Positional After Keyword:
    # âŒ WRONG - SyntaxError
order_pizza(size="large", "thin")

# âœ… CORRECT
order_pizza("large", "thin")  # All positional
order_pizza("large", crust="thin")  # Mix OK if positional first
  4. Forgetting to Return:
    # âŒ WRONG - function does work but doesn't return total
def order_pizza(size):
    total = calculate_price(size)
    print(total)  # Prints but doesn't return!

# âœ… CORRECT
def order_pizza(size):
    total = calculate_price(size)
    print(total)
    return total  # Now caller can use the value

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tips:

  • âœ… Use keyword arguments for clarity: order_pizza("large", delivery=True) is clearer than order_pizza("large", "regular", "mozzarella", [], True)
  • âœ… None for mutable defaults: Always use None for list/dict defaults
  • âœ… Descriptive parameter names: delivery=True is clearer than d=True
  • âœ… Document defaults in docstring: Help users know what defaults are
  • âœ… Optional parameters = flexibility: Start with reasonable defaults, let users customize

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
ğŸ¯ Essential Points to Remember:

  1. Default arguments make parameters optional:
    def greet(name, greeting="Hello"):
    #                ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
    #                Optional with default value
    • Parameters with =value are optional
    • If not provided, the default is used
    • If provided, your value overrides the default
  2. Required parameters must come first:
    # âœ… CORRECT
def func(required, optional="default"):

# âŒ WRONG
def func(optional="default", required):
  3. Three ways to pass arguments:
    • Positional: greet("Alice", "Hi") - order matters
    • Keyword: greet(name="Alice", greeting="Hi") - order doesn't matter
    • Mixed: greet("Alice", greeting="Hi") - positional must come first
  4. Keyword arguments improve readability:
    # Hard to understand
create_user("alice", "alice@email.com", 25, True, False)

# Self-documenting
create_user("alice", "alice@email.com", age=25, active=True, admin=False)
  5. Keyword arguments allow skipping middle parameters:
    def func(a, b="default_b", c="default_c", d="default_d"):
    pass

# Can skip b and c, just change d
func("value_a", d="value_d")
  6. Mutable default argument pitfall:
    # âŒ DANGEROUS - don't use mutable defaults directly
def append_to(item, list=[]):
    list.append(item)
    return list

# âœ… SAFE - use None and create inside
def append_to(item, list=None):
    if list is None:
        list = []
    list.append(item)
    return list
  7. None is useful for "not provided" detection:
    • Different from 0, "", False which are actual values
    • Allows calculating defaults based on other parameters
  8. Mixing rules:
    • Once you use a keyword argument, all following must be keyword
    • Can't do: func(name="Alice", "Hi") - positional after keyword
    • Can do: func("Alice", greeting="Hi") - keyword after positional
  9. Benefits of defaults and keywords:
    • More flexible functions
    • Better code readability
    • Easier to add new features without breaking existing code
    • Users only specify what they need to change

ğŸš€ Coming Up Next:

In the next lesson, you'll learn about lambda functions (anonymous functions) and explore Python's powerful built-in functions like map(), filter(), and sorted() that make your code more concise and Pythonic!

checkpoint_quiz.question: What happens if you don't provide an argument for a parameter that has a default value?
options: The default value is used automatically
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: The default value is used automatically! That's the whole point of default arguments - they make parameters optional by providing a fallback value. If you don't provide a value when calling, Python uses the default from the function definition.

Option C is INVALID because you cannot use a positional argument ("Hi") after a keyword argument (name="Alice"). Once you start using keyword arguments, all following arguments must also be keywords. Options A, B, and D are all valid.

checkpoint_quiz.question: Why should you avoid using an empty list [] as a default argument?
options: The same list object is shared across all function calls
It makes the function run slower
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: The same list object is shared across ALL function calls! Mutable default arguments (lists, dicts) are created ONCE when the function is defined, not each time it's called. This can cause unexpected bugs where data from previous calls persists. Use 'None' as default and create a new list inside the function.
